questions.question_text: A user is having difficulty with video conferencing and is looking for assistance. Which of the following would BEST improve performance?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Quality of service (QoS)

Quality of service (QoS) is a set of technologies and techniques that are used to manage network resources and prioritize certain types of network traffic. QoS is particularly useful for video conferencing, as it can ensure that video traffic is given priority over other types of traffic, such as file transfers or web browsing, to improve performance.

A. Packet shaping is a technique that is used to regulate the flow of traffic in a network. It can be used to limit the amount of bandwidth that certain types of traffic can use.

C. Port mirroring is a technique that is used to copy traffic from one network port to another, typically for the purpose of monitoring or troubleshooting.

D. Load balancing is a technique that is used to distribute network traffic across multiple devices or servers to ensure that no single device or server becomes overwhelmed.

Selected Answer: B
QoS can help reduce lag, jitter, and factors that can negatively affect video call quality.
Of course QoS!!

What is meant by quality of service in networking?
Quality of Service (QoS) is a set of technologies that work on a network to guarantee its ability to dependably run high-priority applications and traffic under limited network capacity. QoS technologies accomplish this by providing differentiated handling and capacity allocation to specific flows in network traffic.

System supports three types of QoS: application QoS, IP QoS and role QoS.

Selected Answer: B
Quality of service
CNAME can be used to direct an domain to another domain. You can do so with A or AAAA as well but it will be domain to an IP.

questions.question_text: A network technician is configuring a new firewall for a company with the necessary access requirements to be allowed through the firewall. Which of the following would normally be applied as the LAST rule in the firewall?

discussion.content: Enforce firewall rules: Firewall rules are used to dictate what traffic can pass between the firewall and the internal network. Three possible actions can be taken based on the rule’s criteria: block the connection (explicit deny), accept the connection, or allow the connection if conditions are met (such as it being secured). It is this last condition that is the most difficult to configure, and conditions usually end with an implicit deny clause. An implicit deny clause means that if the proviso in question has not been explicitly granted, access is denied.

Selected Answer: C
C. Implicit deny is normally applied as the LAST rule in a firewall. Implicit deny is a default rule that denies all traffic that does not match any of the other rules. This means that any traffic that is not explicitly allowed by a previous rule will be blocked by the firewall. It is important to have this rule as the last rule to ensure that no unauthorized traffic can pass through the firewall.

Selected Answer: C
This question is definitely checking your comprehension of the order of operations in firewalls rules - where your implicit deny should always be last, so the prior rules can be considered first/in order.

Selected Answer: C
With implicit deny rule set, it will be found @ the bottom of an IP access-list. Anything not mentioned in the ACL rule-set is to be denied by default, thus acting like a Whitelist for confidentiality.

Selected Answer: C
C. Implicit deny

An implicit deny rule is a catch-all rule that denies all traffic that is not specifically allowed by other rules in the firewall. It is typically applied as the last rule in the firewall's configuration to ensure that any traffic that is not explicitly permitted by other rules is blocked.

A. Secure Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is a protocol that is used to manage network devices.

B. Port security is a feature that is used to restrict access to a switch port based on the MAC address of the device that is connected to the port.

D. DHCP snooping is a security feature that is used to prevent unauthorized DHCP servers from being connected to a network.
In firewalls, implicit deny is the default configuration that blocks traffic that doesn't match a set of rules established in advance.

Selected Answer: A
A. Omni

An omni-directional antenna radiates signal in all directions and is suitable for coverage in a circular area. It is ideal for situations where a wireless access point (WAP) needs to provide coverage in a radius around the radio, as it does not need to be pointed in a specific direction.

B. Directional antenna radiates signal in a specific direction.

C. Yagi antenna is a type of directional antenna that is used in point-to-point wireless communications.

D. Parabolic antennas are highly directional antennas that are primarily used in point-to-point wireless communications, and typically used for long-distance wireless communications.

Selected Answer: A
For indoor use, you are more likely to use omnidirectional

questions.question_text:
A technician wants to install a WAP in the center of a room that provides service in a radius surrounding a radio. Which of the following antenna types should the
AP utilize?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
- Configuring SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) traps on the network would BEST help the administrator determine the cause of the jitter and high latency in the VoIP network.
- SNMP traps can provide real-time notifications of network events, such as high utilisation on a network interface or low memory on a device, that can indicate potential problems. By analysing the SNMP traps, the administrator can identify any underlying issues causing the jitter and high latency, such as network congestion, bandwidth constraints, or device failures.
- While NTP (Option D) can help to ensure accurate timing in the network, which is important for VoIP, it would not necessarily help to directly determine the cause of the jitter and high latency issues. The other options, RADIUS (Option A) and LDAP (Option C), are primarily used for authentication and authorisation. They are not directly related to diagnosing jitter and high latency in a VoIP network.
SNMP traps would allow him to analyze the problem with MIB information collected

Selected Answer: B
Since we are being asked to determine the best way to find a cause - not provide a solution, the answer will be SNMP in order to observe issues in real-time. 
You _could_ take an approach of "trying all the most likely things" without observing the management protocol data- but that's probably not what CompTIA wants to teach you to do.

Selected Answer: B
MIBs can keep track of the management data of a device including it's traffic speeds & bandwidth by using a hierarchical namespaces containing object identifiers information that includes it's variables such as network speeds & temperatures that are reported through SNMP traps.
An example of SNMP variable bindings included in a trap message are as follows:
* Site Name: PR-Branch
* Criticality: High
* Severity: Low
* Alarm Description: High Temperature

Selected Answer: D
NTP updates, QoS classification and link reservation requests, and 
so on. The management plane comprises traffic that allows remote administration 
and monitoring of network appliances, such as SSH, SNMP, NetFlow, and syslog. 
Management traffic is typically directed to the appliance’s loopback address.

QoS regulates VOIP
a lot of the questions from exam topic's net + qs aren't even on the exam. failed using their qs.

Selected Answer: B
Its SNMP, all day long. The question is what would " help the administrator determine the cause of these issues" - SNMP.
NTP just sets the clock.

Selected Answer: D
While RADIUS, SNMP traps, and LDAP are valuable for various network management and security purposes, they are not directly focused on addressing jitter and latency issues in a VoIP network. NTP, on the other hand, directly contributes to maintaining network stability and aids in troubleshooting and analysis of time-sensitive issues like jitter and latency.

Selected Answer: B
"Which of the following would BEST help the administrator determine the cause of these issues?"

Configuring NTP wouldn't help determine the cause of the issue, it would be a solution AFTER determining the cause.

comments.content: Are you a lawyer? :) True. I hope I can challenge the answer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Establishing NTP (Network Time Protocol) on the network would be the BEST option to help the administrator determine the cause of jitter and high latency issues in a VoIP network. NTP is a protocol that is used to synchronize the clocks of devices on a network, which is critical for time-sensitive applications like VoIP. Jitter and high latency can often be caused by clock synchronization issues, and implementing NTP can help to ensure that all devices on the network have synchronized clocks, reducing the likelihood of these issues occurring.

B. Configuring SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) traps on the network would allow the administrator to receive alerts when network devices experience certain events, but it would not directly help in identifying jitter and high latency issues.

comments.content: Your reason to exclude (B) is the reason you should have excluded (D). The SNMP traps would *precisely* allow Admin to identify the cause of the jitter, whereas setting NTP would simply synchronize time on network elements.

NTP might help fix the issue (if due to synchronisity issues) but would NOT " help the administrator determine the cause of these issues", which is the question asked. This is literally what SNMP is for.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Establishing NTP on the network

Jitter and high latency can be caused by a variety of factors, such as network congestion, packet loss, and out-of-sync clocks. By implementing Network Time Protocol (NTP), the systems administrator can synchronize the clocks on all devices on the network, which can help to reduce jitter and latency. The other options (enabling RADIUS, configuring SNMP traps, and implementing LDAP) are not directly related to addressing jitter and latency issues.

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is running a VoIP network and is experiencing jitter and high latency. Which of the following would BEST help the administrator determine the cause of these issues?

choices.B: Configuring SNMP traps on the network

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The answer is D. RFC 1918 is a private IP address. D is the only private address
Private addresses:
10.0.0.0 to 10.255.255.255 (Class A private address range).
172.16.0.0 to 172.31.255.255 (Class B private address range).
192.168.0.0 to 192.168.255.255 (Class C private address range).

Selected Answer: D
RFC 1918 is a Request for Comments (RFC) document that defines a set of private IP address ranges that can be used within a private network. These addresses are not globally unique and cannot be routed on the public internet, but they can be used within a private network to avoid conflicts with public IP addresses.

The private IP address ranges defined in RFC 1918 are as follows:

10.0.0.0 - 10.255.255.255 (10/8 prefix)
172.16.0.0 - 172.31.255.255 (172.16/12 prefix)
192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255 (192.168/16 prefix)
It's important to note that these ranges were reserved for private use and not to be used by public networks.

Selected Answer: D
RFC 1918 as non-routable over the Internet:
• 10.0.0.0 to 10.255.255.255 (Class A private address range).
• 172.16.0.0 to 172.31.255.255 (Class B private address range).
• 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.255.255 (Class C private address range)
Is there a typo here? I'm not seeing a 10.x.x.x address as an option. I see 100.64.0.1 which is not a Class A address. As such only two of the options seem to be private addresses.
